data.title: Harriet (Beach) Walker (1867-1951)
data.meta_description: Is this your ancestor? Compare DNA and explore genealogy for Harriet (Beach) Walker born 1867 Williamson, Tennessee, United States died 1951 Williamson, Tennessee, United States including ancestors + descendants + 2 photos + DNA connections + more in the free family tree community.
data.text:
Ancestors

[sibling(s) unknown]

Descendants

Problems/Questions

Profile last modified 26 Aug 2020 | Created 18 May 2010

This page has been accessed 218 times.

Biography

Family Stories:

Aunt Dora and Aunt Nell (Thomas Walker and Harriet Beech's daughters) -

Harriet Ella Beech and William Thomas Walker were united in holy matrimony on Old Christmas Day, January 6, 1890. Theirs was an ideal marriage. They were near the same age and both loved farm life. They were blessed with good health, a fine family background and a rich spiritual heritage. They shared the large farm house with his parents, George Washington and Ann Greer Walker. He was a Cilvil War Veteran. They were of Irish Extraction.

The first child to bless the home was a girl. She was christened Augusta Ann for her two grandmothers. What a pride and joy to both parents and grandparents. When a boy was born, he was also a pride and joy. He was named for his grandfathers, William George. When Mary Isla came to bless the home, she was named for her mother's sister Mary. Nellie Edna was named for her grandfather Walker's Aunt Nellie and her Aunt Edna Beech. Another boy joined the family, James Walter, named for his father's brother James and his mother's brother Walter. When John Benjamin came, he was named for his great-great grandfathers, John Greer and Benjamin Walker. Then Farris Rowland. He was named for the District Superintendent of the Methodist Church at that time - the church the family attended. Ellis Granville was given his great-grandmother's maiden name, Ellis, with Granville added for double initials. His twin brother, who did not survive, would have been called Dellis Stanley. Allie Eudora, a bundle of joy to the whole family, arrived after the family had moved to a new home about two miles from the Grandparents. She was named for her mother's sister Dora Craig.

These sketches have been collected from parents, grandparents and other relatives who were interested in family history.

Notes

Family History -

Wilma L. (Sullivan) Jeffreys - In the summer time that Aunt Nell lived with Grandma Walker, she either went to school or she would go on trips. So the grandchildren took turns staying with Grandma. All of her grandchildren took turns staying with Grandma, Uncle Ferris's children, Uncle Ellis's children, Uncle Willie's (William George) children and our family. Grandma had a spring that had a "water perpetual pump", I think they called it, that pumped the water all the time up to the spring house beside the house. I liked it because I didn't have to go to the spring to bring up water, and she had an icebox so I didn't have to go to the spring to bring up milk. She always had biscuits every night, and we would have hot biscuits and jelly before we went to bed, which Mama didn't do.

She had a beautiful garden, all around it were herbs and flowers. She had a lot of Sweet Williams in her garden and she grew sweet peas and peonies. She had a large orchard with tame crabapples. She did a lot of apple drying each summer.

She always made the wine for church for sacrament, and the unleavened bread for sacrament. She taught the elementary or grammar school children's Sunday School as far back as I can remember. And could preach as good a sermon as any person I ever heard.
